title: Metals - gold conductor- Ksp of XCl2- IE of X

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The majority of elements in the periodic table are metals. At <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> most metals are solid and share similar physical properties.

(a) A student claims that gold is a good conductor of electricity because it is dense. Do you agree or disagree with this claim? Justify your answer.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

The majority of elements in the periodic table are metals. At <math alttext="298 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> most metals are solid and share similar physical properties.

(a) A student claims that gold is a good conductor of electricity because it is dense. Do you agree or disagree with this claim? Justify your answer.

(b) In a photoelectron spectroscopy experiment, photons with wavelength <math alttext="130 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cause the ejection of <math alttext="6 s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> electrons from gold, but photons with wavelength <math alttext="105 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mn>105</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mstyle></math> cause the electrons to be ejected with greater energy. A student claims this is because the photons with wavelength <math alttext="130 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are higher in energy than photons with wavelength <math alttext="105 nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>105</mn><mtext> nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer in terms of the energies of the photons.

A student investigates a pure metal, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student takes a <math alttext="100.0 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> piece of metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, heats it to <math alttext="500.0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>500.0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, then places it on a <math alttext="1000.0 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1000.0</mn><mtext> g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block of ice at <math alttext="0.0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The ice partially melts, and the final temperature of the metal, ice, and melted water is <math alttext="0.0 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student calculates the experimental value of the specific heat capacity of metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and records it as <math alttext="0.13 joules per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>0.13</mn> <mtext> J/</mtext> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mtext>g</mtext> <mo>·</mo> <mtext>°C</mtext> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>.

(c) Calculate the magnitude of the energy change of metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> during the experiment.

(d) Calculate the mass of ice melted by metal <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (The enthalpy of fusion of ice is <math alttext="330 joules per gram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>330</mn><mtext> J/g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.)

(e) A student claims that the energy transferred to the ice is used to overcome hydrogen bonding between water molecules in the solid ice. Do you agree or disagree with this claim? Justify your answer.

The student takes a sample of <math alttext="X C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the chloride salt of metal <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and mixes it with <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water to form a saturated solution. The value of <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="X C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="4.0 times 10 to the negative 12 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="298 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(f) Write the balanced chemical equation for the change that occurs when solid <math alttext="X C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves in water.

(g) Calculate the concentration of <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the saturated solution.

(h) Will the solubility of <math alttext="X C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> increase, decrease, or remain the same if it is dissolved in <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.10 molar N a C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.10</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mtext>NaCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> instead of distilled water? Explain.

(i) The student gently heats <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mtext> mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the saturated solution of <math alttext="X C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to a temperature of <math alttext="315 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>315</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the enthalpy change of the dissolution process is positive, will the concentration of <math alttext="X with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in the solution be greater than, less than, or the same as when the temperature of the solution was <math alttext="298 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

The first five ionization energies for metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the following table.

Ionization Energies of Metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

First
 Second
 Third
 Fourth
 Fifth

590
 1100
 4900
 6500
 8200

(j) The ionic compound <math alttext="X C l 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is not known to exist. Explain why, using the data in the table above to support your explanation.

For a compound, the energy required to separate the ions in a crystal lattice into individual gaseous ions is known as the lattice energy of the compound. The following table shows the dissociation reactions and the lattice energies for <math alttext="X F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and for <math alttext="Z F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>ZF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (<math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is another metal different from metal <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.)

Dissociation Reaction
 Lattice Energy (<math alttext="in kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>)

<math alttext="X F 2 solid, produces X with a positive 2 charge, gas, plus 2 F with a negative 1 charge, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>XF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace></mrow><mo>→</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 2609

​<math alttext="Z F 2 solid, produces Z with a positive 2 charge, gas, plus 2 F with a negative 1 charge, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>ZF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mtext> F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 2341

(k) Using the information in the table above, predict whether the ionic radius of <math alttext="X with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than, less than, or equal to the ionic radius of <math alttext="Z with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your prediction in terms of periodic properties and Coulomb’s law.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
